So for me , the service was as good as it gets .... helpful , fun , enthusiastic servers including the bartender who gave my gal a full pour of the house red which was great . The food was excellent especially the house salad and the Penne Al Forno (very cheesy) . I had the chicken parmisiagna which I enjoyed entirely . We will be back prolly every time we come to "the City" .
author: Shawn F.

description:
Ok, so it's taken me over 3 years to make it Sodini's even though I live less than a block away. What a fool I was. Sodini's could quite possibly be my new most favorite restaurant.

I went there last night with my husband and a friend. It was a Friday night and we showed up around 9:30 pm. While we waited half an hour for our table, we decided to help ourselves to a little pre-dinner cocktail. I order a dirty kettle martini. The martini was yum, although maybe not as dirty as I like it. 

While we waited and enjoyed our drinks I also took the time to take in the decor. The bar as well as the restaurant were completely covered in Sinatra and other old Italian memorabilia. The atmosphere was homey, very "lived-in" and welcoming. 

My husband ordered the Veg Pizza, I was delicious and very fresh. My friend ordered the steak with a side of veggies which came with a salad or soup. She choose the soup which was, we both agreed, quite possibly the hardiest best testing minestrone we've ever had. If you think you know Minestrone, you got to try Sodini's. I got the Angel Hair Pasta in a Marinara sauce (vegetarian) which was also quite good and fresh tasting. We also shared a serving of the Bruschetta. Very heavy on the garlic with fresh tomatoes. It was absolutely to die for. 

Everything about the place, from the walls and pictures of Sinatra down to the candle lite ambiance, were very inviting, homely and genuine Italian.

This little restaurant is quite a gem. I have to say I usually try to avoid so called Italian restaurants. Something about overcooked pasta and gnarly processed sauces that just don't appeal to me. This place is different, it's got love. It's got character.
author: Carla P.

description: First impression!  Very courteous service and welcoming!  The aroma from the kitchen overwhelming!  My challenge is that I have a restricted diet, so very limited on what I can have, but let me tell ya.  The Polenta was tasty not too dry or soggy, just right!  The calamari was most excellent, crispy and firm.  I also had a Caprese salad, not bad for this time of the year.  I had to sample the pasta, most excellent.  I actually felt as though I was in NYC for a moment....  If you want good service, good food and atmosphere and reasonable prices!  This place will do it!
author: David C.

description: I don't know how thus place had such good ratings - have people not eaten proper Italian??  Poor is all I can say
author: Steven M.

description:
A hundred and fifty reviews later, but none as good as mine. Sadini's occupies a special place in my heart. A place of romance, warmth, trust and love. I've only been here with one person and that's the way it will remain.  
No matter how rushed for time we may have been, no matter how cold or rainy it was, no matter how over crowded it may have seemed, we always made time for it.  In fact, we made it a high priority when we'd drive in from the S Bay. With its white paper tablecloths, candles in chianti bottles, friendly and never pretentious service and the occasional hint of a thick Italian accent form someone two tables down, it lured us back, time after time.

Now the food - We always started with a bottle of wine, red or white, we cared not. Some bread dipped in balsamic and cheese with a sprinkle of chilies and we were off. The house salad with its beans and creamy pesto is one of the simplest I've had in any restaurant, in any city. But its flavors commanded your taste buds to stand at attention, as if to say, get ready, the best is yet to come. 
Entrees are always straightforward family style Italian. From the chicken and eggplant parmigiana, or the rack of lamb, to many variations of pastas and lasagna, you can't go wrong. I'm not saying its Italian cuisine at it's best, I'm saying it's old world Italian done best. No deserts served but I always got something back in the hotel room.

No matter where we sat, the bar, the back room table for two or the main room, it's ambiance is typically that of a bee hive, Buzzzz, Buzzzzz, Buzzzzz! If it had been in San Jose, I don't think we would ever consider it.  It's not always the ambiance that matters but the company you keep.

When we eat here, we left all other troubles outside. We were great friends and lovers, and we held hand. She would draw a heart on the paper table covering to tell me she loved me. Even though, that was then, Sodini's was and still is, us...
author: Ed L.

description:
after living in the north end in boston i have a thing for old school type italian joints that aren't trying to be uber fancy or contemporary.  

i'm a fan of consuming large amounts carbs while sinking into a vinyl covered booth that has seen better days, surrounded with old framed photos of famous and not so famous italian people and of course, listening to frank sinatra.

(embarassing fact:  i used to have that poster of the rat pack that is hanging near the bathroom.)

i can only speak for one of the two vegan dishes on the menu but the North Beach Style Angel Hair does the job in putting me in the appropriate carb coma I require from an italian joint. 

vegans:  you can ask them to make the side of spinach and mushrooms without any butter.
author: Jen I.

description:
Despite its accolades in other posts, I can't really get into this place. My initial experience here was unremarkable, and how that opportunity came about allowed me to get a good deal of exposure to the place.  I had gone in here with my girlfriend and a friend of ours to get a bottle of wine and hang out.  This was early on a Saturday, around 4:00 or so.  We were overcharged for the wine, and hassled by the bartender because we had recently eaten elsewhere and weren't interested in appetizers, etc.

Several hours later the three of us returned plus our friend's date, as we had noticed that the food smelled good during our bar stint.  The experience was very bland and a rip-off to boot (llama taboot taboot).  We got suckered.

In the end, I found the $27 bottle of Behringer Merlot we bought offered at Trader Joes for $8, and am now submitting this post.  North Beach is littered with tourist traps that disguise the couple decent places.  It's like the grail scene in Indiana Jones, ......choose wisely.
author: TJ D.

description: Sodini's rocks...anyone who would give this less than 5 stars should go back to the burbs and stick to Olive Garden....
author: David S.

description:
Today avoiding pressure was hard. He was asking me again about last night. 
"Where'd you go, where are you going, why won't you tell me?" he continued.
 
He looked like a prince wearing that long coat, with a little dog running around his legs.
For such a big guy, his dog Pumpkin looked somewhere in between a stuffed animal or a rat. They trotted together noisily, he had not been able to rest since the break up with his boyfriend.

"I was reading Shah of Shahs on Monday. Yesterday I saw Shine A Light at the Met," I said. 

He and Pumpkin listened. Their footsteps clicked in their matching striped sweaters. Without looking, their brown eyes met an end of the block where we arrived at Sodini's.

"I want me some dark Italian," he said. 
It was nearly dawn. The wind shook me. 
When I asked about the dark Italian, he said, "I just meant Sodini's, sweetie. I'm sorry but I can't play footsie with you."
"Why would I play that with you?" confused, I asked.
"The mood lighting, the candles, the white linens. Look at all this romance. It's insane!"
"Oh, that's what you mean. The mood lighting! I thought you meant you wanted some Italian man."
"That too! Hot man!"

He left Pumpkin outside. 
Inside, he sat into his seat dramatically, nearly whipped the chair backwards. He laughed--so someone  beside us said under their breath, That awful man.

I happen to think him less of an idiot, more of a dear friend who never sleeps.
author: Jenny T.

description: With apologies to my Italian mother, the lasagna is mouth watering goodness.  Service is great, very friendly and prompt.
author: Joshua F.

description:
I've eaten my way through most North Beach Italian restaurants. This is one of my to die for favorites. This delicious little gem is F-A-B-U-L-O-U-S! Yes, I just had to spell it out for ya.  =P

If you eat here, and it's not one of the yummiest Italian restaurants you've ever eaten at (at LEAST top five, if you're a food snob like me), feel free to Yelp bash my ass. I'll take the beating for this joint. This gem exudes the old soul flavor & ambiance of North Beach. The waitress I always get is such a sweetheart.  The bartender is a doll, great attitude/conversationalist/stiff drinks that taste great! I do feel bad I can't remember their names.  :(

Their "house" wine, jewel cabernet is delish. They don't, however, have a desert menu. Eh, whatever. Not important. Come here for dinner and go explore one of the cafes on Columbus for a cannoli later, if you need to satisfy that sweet tooth.
author: Miss Jessica S.

description:
I can't believe I lived in the bay area for so long and never knew about this place.  This place is amazing!  No reservations, no desserts, the type of old family hangouts where good food is always served.

I loved their Cesar salad, especially since it comes with anchovy fillets!  I also loved the linguini with clams in cream sauce.  I know it sounds odd that it combined cream sauce with clams but it was freaking amazing!  It was a huge plate and I could not stop eating it.  It featured both chopped and whole clams with just a hint of garlic!  I was trying to watch what I eat but it was so tasty that my diet just got thrown right out the door! 

But be careful, this is not the kind of place for large groups and you should expect a wait but it's well worth it!
author: May C.

description: This joint rocks! Excellent service, awesome staff all around, and the BEST Italian food. Highly recommended.
author: Ryan G.

description:
There are 3 aspects of Sodini's Green Valley Restaurant that make it the best restaurant in North Beach...

1.  The food is excellent.  Period.  This is old-school homestyle Italian food as you would expect old-school homestyle Italian food to be:  Hearty, heavy, and heavenly...  

2.  It's as if the throngs of tourists visiting SF haven't found out about this place.  Yet.  The clientele is comprised primarily of locals, and when I say "locals", I mean the people who actually live in North Beach.  It has that home-y vibe that you simply can't force or fake.  The staff and the patrons compliment each other perfectly.  Everyone knows everyone here.  The waitresses trade sassy barbs with each other and customers equally, all of it wrapped in that wink-wink-arm-squeeze of good-naturedness you haven't seen or felt since your last family reunion.  

3.  Most importantly, there, at the center of it all, is Ana.  She runs the bar and oversees everything with a style, grace and charm that is equal parts big-city-street-smarts and hometown-girl-next-door sweetness.  She is the one who greets you when you enter through the (usually packed) bar, most often calling out to you over the heads of the lively and boistrous bar patrons with a winning smile and a warm and friendly demeanor that immediately makes you feel as if you've known each other for years and she's sooooo damn happy to see you again, even if it's your first time walking in the door...  And I guarantee it won't be your last.

If you want upscale, expensive, high-end stuffiness, there's always the French Laundry.

If you want to feel like you've come home after a long time away from your closest friends and family, there's always Sodini's Green Valley.
author: Eduardo W.

description: My girlfriend and I have eaten here twice in the past couple of months and both times were disappointed.  The service was very slow and the food was barely average.  They don't take reservations so expect a long wait.  They are understaffed and so the tables sit empty while the busboy is rushing around.  The waitresses are nice but very slow.  The kitchen is slow.  On both occasions our bread was stale.  Our pastas were average at best.  This used to be a great home-style Italian experience, but I feel that it is going downhill.
author: AJ L.

description: One of the cute hole-in-the-wall North Beach trattorias.  Good for a romantic dinner.  The antipasti polenta is really delicious.  My date showed me the ropes on how to jazz up the olive oil and balsamic dip with salt, pepper, oregano, parmesan and chili flakes to give it an extra fun kick.
author: Rick H.

description:
Love this place ... feel like I'm sitting in a little Capone hide-out there and since that's about as close to home as I can feel in this city, its automatically 5 stars. 

but wait ... there's more - good/cheap red wine, great garlic cheese bread, solid chicken parmigiana.  lovely.  I also recommend the calamari and the bruschetta.

I love me some Sodini's!
author: Sarah K.

description:
I was brought to Sodini's one night by two Italian-American dudes I worked with--Italian Athletic Club members, total Gino&Carlo types.

We drank, told dirty jokes, drank, grubbed, drank, and then took shots.

I puked in the bathroom.

But, ive been back at least three times, and Im never disappointed.  Excellent atmosphere(everyone looks good when the lights are dimmed, right?).
Good service...very attentive.
Good food and wine.  Not the best ever, but for a tiny spot with a great atmosphere, EAT, DRINK, AND BE MERRY!
author: Ryan R.

description:
Hands down my favorite Italian in SF.  The chicken parmesan was always prepared perfectly.  I miss this place more than I can say.

Only downsides - it's tough to get a table during peak dinner hours so get there early or late.  Obviously parking is a nightmare.   And it's quite cramped.

But it's a great date spot. Never had a bad meal here.
author: Eugene K.

description: Hmm...our panini turned out to be a toast! It was not a bad tasting toast, but it was definitely not a panini. Maybe they had run out of the right kind of bread???
author: Anna J.

description:
I met a friend for dinner here a few nights ago and was very impressed!  We had a great window table that was lit by a couple candles in the window.  When I walked into this place it smelt delicious and I could not wait to devour anything they put in front of me.

To my surprise, my friend already ordered some steamed mussels in a garlic wine sauce so I didn't have to wait a moment to start enjoying them and OH MAN were they amazing.  The sauce that they came swimming in was to die for!  Our next course was a beef tortellini in a white sauce (forgive me I don't know what was exactly in it, 2 generous pours of red wine will make you forget a lot of things).  That tortellini did not stand a chance.

My friend is from the east coast and he said that it reminded a lot of little restaurants back home.  It is very causal and a great place to gather with friends or take someone on an intimate dinner.  It is a great dinner and I will undoubtedly be going back!
author: Katie H.

description:
I hold this restaurant partially responsible for me maintaining my weight while expending huge calories walking 20-30 miles a week.  I give my good 'friend' Lorraine, who introduced me to this place, the rest of the responsibility.

With a small, cramped dining area and a tiny bar, Sodini's shouldn't be as much a favorite of mine as it is.  But there is an undefinable warmth to the service and the space that bring me back and has me recommending it to others.  Everyone always seems to be having a wonderful time - almost like the sit-down portion of a huge and mildly raucous family wedding.  

Be warned - portions can be obscenely huge.  Oh, and if you are at all worried about the fit of your clothing just stay away.
author: Suzanne B.

description: Great food, service and atmospher.  Prices are reasonable for the quality of the food you get.  If your near here needing lunch or dinner make sure you stop in.
author: Mike P.

description: This place is amazing! It has a lovely feel, Linda our server was beyond friendly and funny, and both the wine and food was perfect.  I had a mouth watering chicken dish and my boyfriend ordered a steak, I do not even like steak , but I tried a bite and it was unbelievable.  Our other friend who is a vegetarian said that she almost wanted a bite of the steak too due to how amazing it smelled. (don't worry she didn't).  Also they don't take reservations, serve desert or decaf, and I appreciate that.  They do what they do, and you either like it or you don't.  I for one Love It!
author: Deanna W.

description:
Does this place really need review number 146?  Hell.  Yes.  Because, in the infamous words of the New Kids on the Block, It's got "The Right Stuff".  Baby.

What's that, you ask?  Well, history and character, to start, and it's a bit off the beaten path, away from the tourist bee hives of Columbus.  And a damn fine Gnocchi Al Pesto.  My friend raved about the Caesar Salad, declaring it the best in SF.  She was drunk at the time, but I trust her judgment, even inebriated judgment.  Sodini's has become my go-to place for out of town guests.

Not to mention, Sodini's is the only place that can draw me out of my self-imposed Vodka exile.  I don't know what the bartender does to them, but the Gimlets make me forget the fateful night many years ago when I, as a naive college freshman, decided it would be fun to partake in some Cherry Jello-Vodka Shots before going to a frat party.  

And I have never seen Jello or another frat party since then...
author: Sarah J.

description:
This is a local restaurant, with local patrons.....and it's fun !

This is not gourmet italian...it's basic, homemade, standard and good.  Don't come expecting haute cuisine.  I LOVE THE SEAFOOD LINGUINI

Do come and enjoy Anna, Linda, and Rachel, my favorite hostesses and servers....they recognize regulars and treat everyone like family.

They don't take reservations, so if it's not a Monday or Tuesday be prepared to wait..this is a popular local spot.
author: David S.

description: Amazing!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Best meal we have had all weekend. Lasagna was Incredible. Piaza was the best!!!!! Locals eat tbere but they had a very welcoming atmosphere. Wished we lived closer to eat it again.
author: J G.

description: Should I write this?  I don't need more people at my place.  But the rack of lamb is so perfectly seasoned and cooked and such a bargain, I can't contain myself.  Love the bartenders, love the waitresses, love the attitude (or lack of).  Just go.  And then don't come back, because I want my seat back.
author: Bibi M.

description: Great date spot, sit in the window with candle light.  Food is okay go for the atmosphere, very NYC.
author: Mark W.

description: I love this place!  We always talk about trying something new but can never bring ourselves to do it--we love this restaurant so much.  The food is great, home-style Italian and very reasonably priced.  The atmosphere is cozy .  The place is family-owned and the people are incredibly friendly.
author: Anne and Mike M.

description: My brother in law & his wife took me here last night for dinner. This place is an old school family restaurant. The salad was great, the Tortellini Carbonara was excellent. The drinks are great. The owner Mark treats you like family. The place doesn't take reservations but it doesn't matter because this restaurant is worth the short time I had to wait. If your in San Francisco, check this place out. You won't be disappointed.
author: Bernie B.

description: I am surprised that this restuarant in North Beach does not have more reviews! We came here on a Sat. night and was surprised that it closed so late! I grew up in North Beach and was never a fan of Italian food because every Italian restaurant was the same to me. However, I really fell in love with this restuaurant because it was very charming. We ordered the pesto gnocchi, margarita pizza and chicken parm. The ingredients tasted very fresh and light, which I liked! I loved the pesto gnocchi:) The service was excellent. I will definitely return if I am craving Italian and in the neighborhood!
author: Rosanna T.

description:
Was looking for a place in North Beach as had a friend visiting staying around there. Picked this place based on the yelp reviews, as figured it would help me navigate the minefield that can be touristy stodgy north beach Italian restaurants.

It is a cute place, but then again, most of the restaurants in North Beach are.  We got a table straight away, but it was pretty full.  I have to make a special mention of the staff here, they were all super friendly, down-to-earth, helpful and great.

The food was OK.  The bread they give you is ordinary at best, but their olive oil is pretty yummy.  Ordered some garlic bread and caprese salad appetizers-they were fairly awful.  The mozzarella on the salad was like a brick- or make that mini bricks as it came in those rounds between the tomatoes.  The garlic cheese bread was made on the same gross bread they put on the table when you sit down.  It was pretty gross and not like  a beloved classic garlic bread at all.  All of us ordered gnocchi for our main course.  The gnocchi was actually really yummy-stuffed with spinach and cheese and fluffy.  I got just a plain tomato sauce on top of it, which was super fresh and flavorful.  The boys got a meaty creamy looking sauce that was pretty funky looking, not in a good way.  The portions were decent but not stuff-you crazy big, which is a plus for me.  

I would go back for gnocchi if I was in the area but I wouldn't trek across town for the restaurant, and I'd be wary of ordering other stuff on the menu, based on what I saw around me on other tables.

North beach dining has yet to convince me, I'm"m still thinking it's all  mostly a tourist trap.
author: Carlin S.

description:
Text message at 3:31 pm - Dinner drinks tonight?  I'm not sure where yet...But meat (Jeff's nickname is meatball, don't ask) wants some meat...Let me know if you are interested.

Text back:  Sounds good, what time and who else is going?

Several phone calls later the decision is still in the air.

Text message at 8:29 pm - Sodini's on Grant and Green.  One block up from Columbus...meet us there at 9.

I jump in the vehicle at 8:45 pm and head over to North Beach.  (Running late, no time to hail a cab in South Beach).  Find parking in front of Avenue G, check my watch and note the time.  9 PM.  Perfect.  I'm so money and I don't even know it.  I walk the block over to Sodini's and meet my friends.

There are 6 of us in total, and on a quiet Tuesday night, it was perfect.    No waiting for a table, we had an attentive waitress, it looked like we had the place to ourselves.  What more could we ask for?  

I ordered the seafood linguine which was delicious, full of calamari, clams, and shrimp, its paired with this creamy sauce that was amazing.  

Cool factor: Crayons in a glass.  Doodle while you wait for your food.
author: Dennis M.

description: We were walking thru North Beach one night, and we decided to stop in at Sodini's.  They had just turned off their lights because it was a slow evening, but we decided to go in anyway.  We came in on Elvis' birthday, and of course they were playing Elvis music!  Very nice atmosphere and friendly staff.  I got the 12" #1 pizza.  12" might seem small, but its bigger than you'd think.  I'm writing this review a week late, so I can't remember all the extra witty things I was going to say about Sodini's, but you should check it out anyway.  It's good stuff.
author: Stefan K.

description:
Telegraph Hill is a neighborhood I rarely experienced until this year. When I was in college, birthdays and celebrations in North Beach were common, but   I never got past Columbus until this past year when I discovered the charms of Grant Street.

Grant Street is filled with classic businesses, friendly bars, and delicious restaurants: my favorite being Sodini's. I did not know there was more to the name, so if you prefer to be formal, it is Sodini's Green Valley Restaurant.

About a week ago, I was with two of my wine-drinking, glamourous, career-executive type female friends, Christine and Blair. As these girls know good wines and great food, I need to make great suggestions. 

When the pirate bar was closed for a private party, I had to think fast and Sodini's came to mind. Christine and I have burned through most of the typical North Beach restaurants and we avoid certain ones to avoid a crazy car, a crazy waiter, a bad menu, or all of the above. I had never been before, but I knew it would be a wonderful experience for all of us.

Upon arrival on a Tuesday, the wait was about ten minutes. We ordered a bottle of wine for maybe $30.00, which tasted more like $50.00. My friends had a cigarette and when they returned, we were seated at a cozy table. The place was full, but we were still able to chat without hearing everyone else's business.

Our waitress and the person behind the bar were wonderful, they were friendly, full of personality, and great servers. In terms of food, we ordered appetizers, calamari and garlic bread. Then, my friend ordered a seafood pasta and I ordered there special angel hair pasta, which was the cheapest on the menu, but exactly what I wanted. My other friend ordered a salad, which she enjoyed. During dinner, we ordered another bottle of wine and our waitress brought over a complimentary order of garlic bread, she knew we would eat it.

By the end of the evening, we were all full and satisfied. Then, the night got better when my song came on, it goes, "hey mambo, mambo italiano, hey mambo...." Then, when I went to the restroom, my friend requested the song again for me and it made me extra happy.

I thought the prices were reasonable. It was about $120.00 for two bottles of wine, two appetizers, three main courses, and a side dish, plus tax and a huge tip. 

I highly suggest going to this place if you love home-cooked Italian food. If you are local and don't know this place, you need to go. If you are from out of town and want to find a charming spot, this is the place to go.
author: Christopher W.

description:
I like this place.  It's always busy.  You might wait at the bar.  You'll stand and order glass after glass of the sangiovese, then when the table is ready, you'll sit and have a big meal in a comfortable, Italian restaurant that feels like they've been doing it this way for many, many years.
Not super fancy, just honest Italian food.
I think some other Yelpers who vote with one star have to take a little reality check and turn down the drama a little.
So what, if they someone may not greet you at the door.
So what, if they're busy and the service is a little slow.
Relax.  Slow down.  Don't rush your food.  Enjoy a little wine and have an interesting conversation with the people you came with.
author: Kev M.

description:
Solid 4 stars.  Food was great, staff was friendly, atmosphere was very cozy.  (It was rainy so finding a cozy place was a requirement)  Had to wait for a table for about an hour but generally don't mind waiting, if you do this spot/area might not be your cup of tea.

Would definitely return here.  (But not too soon since there are so many great restaurants in San Francisco)
author: John A.

description:
Okay, I come from an italian family who takes italian food SERIOUSLY. I brought my Aunt and Uncle here when they were in town visiting and we were NOT disappointed. The marinara (on the angel hair pasta) rivals my mothers and the fried calamari that we had as a starter was probably the best I have ever had. Small, old school rustic atmosphere with Northern Italian comfort food makes this place an A+++.
PS Reasonably price too with nice wine menu!
author: Jess W.

description:
Updated!

My ABSOLUTE FAVORITE Rack of Lamb.  Yep, delicious... oh and that brochette for an appetizer... can't beat it.  Prices are even better.  I've been about a dozen times.  I love the Lynda especially.  She calls me Beth even though I'm Mariah.  We had a few good laughs about that.  Beth was easier to say and hear in a crowd.... I guess... LOL... Mark was very friendly as well.  Can't forget Ana!  She's easy on the eyes ;) and really knows how to engage her customers!

All in all, this is one of my favorite places to go.
author: Noneya B.

description: Wow. Been eating here for years and always order the same thing...lamb chops side of pesto gnocchi...chops came out raw, sent back and the middle was still salmon colored. When I pointed this out to the waitress she told me she looked at it in different lighting and I was wrong! I never did eat the lamb. The owner, Mark, came by and took off my bill (actually he rudely flipped the check on my table)  but offered nothing else. I've been here countless times and never once had a complaint... I'm really disappointed about their response the first time I did.and yes, for the first time in my life I did not tip the wait staff...the service was that bad...See my previous excellent review was my first on yelp...UPDATE 7/26: I did receive a response from Sodini's but it was very rude and offensive. I will post separately.
author: Jeff P.

description:
A very unusual place. It's family owned and operated for like a thousand years. It's usually crowed, very crowded, so your table with be almost butted up against the ones on either side of you but it's like being in a Italian family kitchen. The food is very good as is the service.

Make a reservation, go early, sit at the bar. If you order drink(s) I find that you tend to get a table faster...Ana (of course one of the family) is there to make you a smashing Negroni or some other interesting Italian drink,

 The food is all good and so are the desserts..everything like Mama Mia would make in her home kitchen and very large portions so order as you go along not all at one time.
author: Lee S.

description:
I just moved here from Minneapolis and am a runner & cyclist.  What a better place to be than in Carb heaven?  

Our beloved landlords suggested this place, saying it was "more authentic, and less touristy."  We've been there twice, and despite realllllly wanting to like this place.......

This place is not special.  

There is nothing exciting about the menu.  We generally don't eat meat, and love seafood.  No problem - we like simple, so how about spaghetti or ravioli?  

The sauce could have come from a can, as far as I can tell.  

The second time I tried a pasta tube filled with cheese and covered in red sauce.   The sauce was as expected.  It was also draped with a disgusting amount of mozzerella.  

I won't go back.
author: Stryrker S.

description:
As long as you don't mind waiting, it's one of the best bets in North Beach.  Put your name down and take a stroll.

Don't wait by the bar - for some reason, the bartender has a big old chip on his shoulder.  He treats you like you're a tourist asking for directions!  What an asshole.  Everything else is great - one of the best bargains in SF.
author: Chris R.

description:
So sad...  After a long absence I visited this old favorite in North Beach.  It was not the same, so much so I asked the waitress if there had been an ownership change.  The answer was no.  In any case, they were severely understaffed.  It took 45 minutes to be served and we had been seated immediately...  We shared an appetizer of Bruschetta which was OK, but we'd gone through a couple of small loaves of bread while waiting as we were hungry.
The entrees finally arrived, we had each ordered the Fetuccini,  with meat for him and seafood for me.  While my seafood was OK, the sauce was nothing special but at least the pasta was cooked well.   I felt so sorry for my companion as his pasta was severely overcooked.  It wasn't even the Fetucinni on the menu but a severely overcooked slimy spaghetti.  Something left over from another order?  I tasted it and we agreed it was awful!  It  was reminiscent of something from a cafeteria!  Slimy pasta and a tasteless sauce!  I felt awful as I had recommended this place...  I suggested reordering but he didn't want to wait another 45 min.
On another note, do not order the wines by the glass!  To be fair, I've never ordered wine by the glass  here, always a bottle.  This time my guest did not drink so I was on my own.  I ordered both the Cabernet and Chianti by the glass and they were the worst ever.  The waitress did bring me another glass which was nice, but I goggled the wine and a bottle of Esser Cab retails at $8 the same as a glass there! What do you suppose the bulk price was? 
Perhaps it was an off night, but I fell terrible.  I told my friend I knew of a cool little place in North Beach and we were both ever so let down.
author: Kara H.

description:
I was here for a little rrrrrrromantique late dinner, going on the advice of yelp and friends we'd been drinking with over at Vesuvio. Our quest was to get off of Columbus and it's overrated, tourist filled eateries and find somewhere with a combination of words such as "venerable," "old-school," "authentic," and, of course, "delicious." 

The place was lively and had a great vibe on a Saturday night. The patrons are eclectic and the outside tables are a great place to people watch. (If you're not a frat boy, you might want to avoid the clubs across the street.) The service was great and the food was generally delicious. The Caesar was crisp had lots of real anchovies on it, and though the minestrone was different than I'm used to, (less chunky and with a bit of cream,) it was delightful. My chicken Marsala was of the best I've had, but the side of pasta only had a bit of Bolognese over it. (What good is perfectly cooked pasta if you don't get enough sauce for it!?) The gnocci was super fluffy and the pesto was delicious and generous, albeit borderline too-salty for me. The only other complaint I have is that the heaters could not be adjusted. The weather barely warranted them and being on the fair side, I've been 'sunburned' by those things before.

The bathroom photo made me giggle: the usually well composed, gracious and fabulous all around Sophia Loren sideways glancing, half snidely checking Jayne Mansfield's inappropriate cleave. My date had a similar reaction in the men's room to a rat packish photo of Dean Martin and co., with Frank Sinatra looking particularly cranked off his gourd. I applaud the tongue in cheek humor evident in the selection of these snaps.

I'm being a bit generous and tipping the last star forward, concentrating on the overall experience rather than the foibles with food.
author: Nomi G.

description: What can I say...I simply love this place.  May faves are any of the pizzas and you got to have the clams!
author: Denise C.

description: Came in with my family and for the six of us we ordered a bunch of stuff to share.  Calamari, salad, a couple of pizzas, a couple of different gnocchi dishes, a chicken dish and several jugs of house wine to wash it all down.  Everything was really good.  I'm not usually a fan of gnocchi but I really liked the gnocchi here, especially the one with the Gorgonzola cream sauce.  I even liked my least favorite thing on the table, the chicken dish, I just liked everything else even more.  Our waitress was big and brassy and seemed like she might be a bit surly but any concerns quickly disappeared because she was super friendly and gave us great service.  One of the owners was bartending and I swear he looked like he had just walked off the set of Goodfellas but he couldn't have been a more gracious host.  I was tempted to knock off a star for overemphasizing Frank Sinatra in the music and decor at the expense of the great Dean Martin but I'll let it pass because this was the best meal I've had in an Italian restaurant in a long time.
author: Blevins L.

description:
I don't get to North Beach all that often, and when I do, I'm looking for Italian food that is transcendent.  Unfortunately, Sodini's was not the place.

The food was good, but not great. I enjoyed the calamari, but the penne pesto was just so-so. The penne was overcooked and watery. The sauce was good, not great. Rather than having the penne added to the pan with the sauce, the sauce was poured over the pasta.  This meant there was way too much sauce and the pasta was not well coated.  Also, because of the watery-ness of the pasta, the sauce did not stick.  It seems a small thing, but it is the small things that make a difference between good and extraordinary food.   My partner had the linguine with cream sauce, which was kind of bland.

The service could have been better. The waitress put the plates down and fled without asking if we wanted anything else. We did: fresh ground pepper and Parmesan cheese. After waiting a bit, we called over the manager (owner?) because he was standing nearby. He quickly got us some pepper, but also pointed out the jar of dry grated cheese on the table. I guess for Italian food in this price range I expect fresh grated or shaved Parmesan.  It has a pungency and moistness that can't be found in the Kraft canned style cheese they had on the table.  To perhaps excuse the waitress a bit, she was otherwise fine, and she was very busy.

Pluses:  the atmosphere was fun and they have Italian beer on draft.  The place has a fun atmosphere and is not touristy.  It seems to be a local's favorite - it was recommended by a tender in a nearby bar.   But basically, the food was good, but not special, and there are a lot of other places nearby to try, so I don't think we will hurry back.
author: Vernon M.

description:
First off, in North Beach, if you're going to do Italian, you want to go somewhere with an atmosphere and this place has it. Dark, rustic, old fashioned, basic Italian food, nothing fancy just good old fashioned cooking. 

Calamari is good, as well as the mozzarella caprese salad. For my entree I had the tortellini with mushrooms, pancetta and a creamy sauce which was so amazing, that despite my plan to only eat half and save the rest ( I am trying to fit into a wedding dress in 2 months afterall) I ended up eating the entire thing in one sitting. 

Service is fast and efficient and friendly, exactly what you'd expect from a neighborhood restaurant. For 3 of us we spent $120, for 2 appetizers, 3 entrees and a pitcher of red wine. 

Perfect place for a good dinner out.

FYI - they are really basic- so much in fact they don't take reservations and don't serve dessert.  But they do take credit cards.
author: Denise B.

description: Best true Italian restaurant in SF bar none.  Right in the heart of North Beach.  I've been coming here for more than 20-years now and have never had a bad meal or experience.  A great family owned and run restaurant.  The food and service are outstanding.  You will likely need to wait during peak hours, so plan on bellying up to the bar, having a nice glass of Chianti, and making a new friend or two all while listing to Frank or Deno...
author: Rudy M.

description: unexpected gem.  Was hungry while waiting to meet some friends at the bar across the street. Friendly staff and dining guests and the food made it even better.
author: Rachel S.

description:
I very rarely make it out of SF without eating at Sodini's   I love this place.  It is small, and so if you want to eat there on a Saturday night, get there early.  Plan on waiting an hour for a table if you arrive later, and take advantage of that time and have a drink (or three) at the bar.  Anna's cosmo's are really the best I have ever had. The Gnocchi Pesto is divine.  You can color on your table due to the white sheets of paper and the crayons.  I have always been treated like a queen when I go there, and that, along with the gnocchi, is the reason I keep going back.  And I suppose that it doesn't hurt that Mark Sodini is one handsome devil and pours a mean glass of wine.
I have never been disappointed by Sodini's.
author: Tracey Lee D.

description:
Came here based on the rating on Yelp. I am an old-school Italian guy and thats what I found at Sodini's. Nothing fancy, waitresses aren't afraid to curse, restaurant doesn't try to be something its not. 

Their house salad was spectacular. I had their chicken with ham and cheese. I would of preferred prosciutto for the ham but overall it was good. Girl had the gnocchis, which were different but still good. 

I would like to go again and try some house favorites. Don't expect anything fancy, this is a home-owned italian kitchen not a 5 star restaurant.
author: Jason N.

description:
I LOVED this place!  After a really good meal and some really awesome wine, the bar tender and his buddy taught me to play liar's dice.  Even the customers were all friendly and chatted me up all night.
I've never had a better "alone" dinner.

It was so funny for me to be in SF and totally feel like I was in South Philly or my uber italian aunt's house.  I literally stumbled into this place because the shoes I was wearing were killing me and I was starting to get hungry and later found out what a landmark it was!

They don't make their own pasta, but it's delivered fresh daily and they do make all of their own sauces.  BIG PLUS--they don't overcook things (i.e. mooshy gnocchi), and don't think al dente means hard.

I will definitely go back there again when I'm in town.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
It seems to me that this is THE PLACE to go if you are in the mood for some basic Italian fare. I realized recently that I prefer simple pasta dishes and stuff to fancy Italian food. Maybe you don't , and that's cool, because there are lots of fancy places to eat in SF if that is your thing.

My boyfriend and I went to Sodini's on Saturday night. We didn't have to wait very long. I had some lasagna which was delicious...all melty cheese, meaty meat, and not too much sauce.  That's all I had (and a cocktail. Good cocktail!) so I can't comment much more on the food, but here are some other things which made Sodini's awesome:

1. Crayons on the table to draw with on the butcher paper covering the tables. Yeah, yeah, I know this is a common feature of chain Italian restaurants, but we got more than three colors! So, awesome.

2. Frank Sinatra crap everywhere.

3. The couple next to us who were on a first date, and I'm pretty sure they met online. They seemed like a coupla good kids. I hope it works out for them. I know Sodini's isn't responsible for this couple, but I'm giving it to them anyway.
author: Leata H.

description: Great location. . .Excellent food . . .Beautiful people. . . A must stop on the North Beach dinner tour.  Don't miss Sodini's!
author: William B.

description:
After three Absinthes, a bottle of Pinot Noir, bruschetta, mussels, and macking salads with great friends...
...does it matter that my rack and my friends NY were overcooked?
No.  
Definitely not.
It's always just way too fun here.  
Still tops for my favorite Italian in The City.
While leaning up on the wall waiting for our table...
...saw Sodinis took "best of" for Italian in The Weekly.
Good for them! Hope it doesn't change anything.
Connor, I ate your leftover NY last night.
It's a damn shame you paid too.
Ha~!
author: Barry A.

description:
Sodini's ranks high on my list for several reasons:
*The menu is not pretentious-the food precisely accomodates the diner who fancy's Italian-American flavor with no Fluff (an important quality for a person who appreciates consistency).
*Sodini's doesn't put a "twist" on Italian-American fare, nor does it serve more plate then food- this is a "down to business" hearty neighborhood restaurant. 
*Great wine pairings are also available to wash down the honest portions. 
*Must try: Beef Lasagna, Lamb-chops, Minestrone, NY Steak, R. Mondavi Sangiovese.
*Good Music- Sinatra, Dino, Prima, Vale, and Monte can always be heard  on the speakers.
author: Coco M.

description:
Dude...FOUR effin Stars?!?! Are you kidding me? 
How the Hell does this place get Four stars..!?!?
 I was lead here by a Sodini ex-believer..

Let me explain the 'EX'..

A group of us went in for dinner one night. The Sodini ex-believer swears by this restaurant. Best Italian food in town..blah..dee..blah..no place like this.blah..blah and on and on and on...
So I had high expectations for this place and judging from the outside decor it had some promising characteristics.
Romantic candlelight tables (Window seating only)
Inconspicuous location (always a plus)

However, what goes on inside is another story!
We were not greeted when we walked through the door? Geez...Where is the Love?
We had a attitudey, brain-less server! The girl was an idiot! Kept getting the drink order wrong, brought us plates that we did not order, ignored us half the time.. It was just bad, bad service! 
The only good thing that came out of our meals is the soup in the beginning and the side order of spinach with mushrooms! That's it! 

The Sodini's special chicken I had was disgusting. Dry and flat piece of Chicken breast smothered in what they call Mozzarella but taste more like Government cheese with a slab of thin oscar-meyer ham on top. Accompanied by over-cooked angel hair in canned tomato sauce that was cold. Al-Dente pasta my ASS!!

Another person had the seafood pasta with tomato and heavy cream base. The angel hair pasta she had would fall apart every time she picked them up. (Another sign of Al-Dente gone wrong) There was also still alot of sand in the seafood. No, not the little bits of crumble where you can just ignore or think "Daym, this seafood must be fresh" But the nightmare you get when you are buried alive in the beach and a wave of sand and water comes rushing in your mouth. (Yes, I am very imaginative)

The ex-believer had the Chicken Parmesan with a side of rigatoni pasta. They don't bread their chicken so he was served a piece of dry, flat chicken also. 

The meal portions were huge but that's not why we didn't finish even half! After dinner, the ex-believer paid the tab and hung his head in shame. 

He was a believer no more.....
author: H To The W.

description:
Sodini's is a classic.  You'll always feel welcome when you set foot in this restaurant (even when Mark's killer Manhattans knock you on your ass).  From the bartenders to the servers to the cooks, everyone is a class act.  

And the linguine with clams is to die for!  I'm so glad I live so very close by.
author: Jessica B.

description: I love this place! So quaint, so special.... I recommend Sodini's should add a gluten-free option of pasta and then it'd be the perfect 5 star restaurant!
author: Honest Y.

description:
Ventured here on a spontaneous Tuesday evening date to North Beach.

Dinner was going to be either this place or the pizza place (Golden Boy..?) next door. We opted for the sit down for a pleasant discovery!

FOOD: 
Caprese - $9ish, tasted very fresh and light. Perfect appetizer. They ended up splitting the dish in two (knowing that we wanted to share), which I found to be a nice gesture =)

Seafood Linguini - $15ish, and let's just say they don't skimp out on the seafood - succulent shrimp, squid, clams, mussels, the whole shebang! Overall though, the flavor was perfectly savory - not bland as far as most pasta dishes can be. Very good portion as well (had leftovers!)

Pesto Gnocchi -- $10ish. OMG so tender and soft and melt in your mouth kinda good. (We ate here about a week ago, and I can still imagine the wonderful texture...or maybe I'm just craving it now..). 

SERVICE: Friendly, but a bit slow/unattentive...I think we waited about a good 20 minutes or so before our waitress took our orders. I think there were only 2 waitresses the entire evening, but the place was packed...so I can partially understand. Nonetheless, they might want to consider getting more staff?

AMBIANCE: Authentic homey Italian feel, which was pleasantly refreshing. Though, a bit on the noisy side (most likely bc our table for 2 was right next to a huge birthday party of 10+ people) and hard to hear each other. 

OVERALL: I would definitely like to come back for the food for sure! However, not a place I would go out of my way to come back for. Perhaps if I were in the North Beach area again.
author: Gail N.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this quaint neighborhood haunt. The food is fantastic (go for the mountain of calamari) and the ambiance is just as great. You might need to wait a little while for a table as it's a very popular place, but have no fear, you have a friendly bartender that is waiting to pour you a glass of wine or cocktail during your wait. 

Even if I move out of the neighborhood, this is definitely a restaurant I would come back to over and over again, no matter where I am.
author: Mollie M.

description:
I, too, am not really one for hanging out in North Beach...but I was craving Italian food and my friend suggested we go and walk around until we found a place that looked good...we spotted Sodini's, and even though the hostess told us there was a 40 minute wait (turns out it was much less than that)...we pulled up to the bar and enjoyed the wait...it was definitely a local hang and i like that.

The food was simple and great...we shared a salad that they pre-split for us...the house dressing was lovely...the house red was delicious...the angel hair pasta with marinara, sun-dried tomatoes  and spring onions was just what I wanted...the no dessert thing was no problem as I had no room for it anyway...fortunately it was a nice evening so took a long walk with a happy belly full of food...
author: Laura F.

description:
I love Sodini's.  

The staff is wonderful (be sure to have a drink at the bar with Ana,)

the ambiance superb (dim lighting, Rat Pack theme,)

you will need a to-go box,

more than reasonable prices,

I wish they were open for lunch!!

Out of towners visiting?  Take them here!
author: Michelle W.

description:
came here on a saturday night for dinner. parking was a biotch.
nice and warm here, i liked our waitress because she had on like 50 gold chains.
i ordered the pesto tortellini and my friend ordered the gnocci with meat sauce.
my dish was aiight but hers was sooo good! if i ever happen to be in the neighborhood again i'd come back and have the gnocci :)
author: v g.

description: Walked up without a reservation on a Saturday about 5:30 and had no trouble getting a seat.  The host seems to be the owner and he had a warm welcoming for us.  Waitress was friendly and helpful offering suggestions on the menu.  I had the veal scallopini, and my wife had a chicken marasala special, both with linguini with red sauce. Both were very goo, especially if you like mushrooms.  We both had salads and I had the caesar, which in most places is just romaine lettuce with industrial dressing. This one had a little bite, lots of grated cheese and the waitress offered anchovies.  Bread was ok, not great.   Wine prices were reasonable.  A great classic family Italian restaurant.
author: John S.

description: So girlfriend and I are on the hunt for some North Beach Italian... We scour Yelp for something new and come up with Sodini's. I've been in town for a while and have tasted my share of North Beach's Italian fare. Let's get to it. Sodini's gives you exactly what you pay for; good food at a moderate price. The calamari is bomb (ask for a side of marinara). The lady had shrimp and mussels over linguini, I had chicken marsala. Our entrees were very tasty. Not out of this world, yet really satisfying. Decent portions and solid service. Minus the slightly hooky Sinatra and Godfather get up and this place is well worth your time and your money. In a typical North Beach fashion you get exactly what you pay for.
author: Daniel C.

description: We got this place recommended by a friend. I checked Yelp: 4 stars. Let's give it a shot. As soon as I saw the menu I had second thoughts but all 7 of us were seated. I didn't feel like causing a stink. However the stink was caused by someone else. The kitchen. The clams and mussels to be precise. 1 star at best. We ordered salad, calamari, gnocchi, pasta and pizza. I felt terrible leaving plates where we had hardly touched the food but it wasn't just average - it didn't taste good. We left hungry, paid the $300(!) bill and got gelato down the street. I do realize that I may come off as a snob in this review but I can assure you that living in SF simply offers plenty of opportunities to eat FANTASTIC food, sometimes even at a pretty affordable price. However Sodini's offers neither. To top it all off the service was close to non-existent, which to me is secondary to the food but it's worth mentioning. This is a generous 2 star review of a restaurant that has proven that SF can still use plenty more competition in the restaurant business. Never again.
author: Jonas O.

description:
I've been in here twice and would go back again.  
Great ambiance, great bartender.  It's close quarters inside, but the waitstaff makes it easy to feel like the restaurant is less crowded.  They are really attentive.   Prices were reasonable and portions large, plan on taking some of your dinner home for lunch the next day.  
The first meal was good enough to make me go back a second time,  (and would have should have given four stars).  The second time I went for dinner I had the pesto and it was mediocre.   It was missing that 'pop' that most pesto has and was a little too creamy for my taste.  But the salad and the wine were both great. 
I'm looking forward to having dinner here again, and bumping this up to four stars.
author: E P.

description: I brought family there from Australia recommended from a friend and it was the worst food ever. The service was OK and the food tasted like it was out of a can . So embarrassed !
author: Jack E.

description: I work in the North Beach neighborhood myself and love the feel of this place. The gnocchi is excellent and the calamari is a wonderful way to get your cholesterol levels to the appropriate place: happiness. I love the no-nonsense wait staff-- they are succinct without being rude, and the Sinatra paintings and vintage photos allow me to pretend I'm in another time, another place.
author: Brigid S.

description:
Very authentic experience.  You will feel like you are in a friend's dining room eating. Everyone we interacted with was pleasant and swift. 

The food was great!! I had the seafood linguine. I have to say that I've never seen a plate of pasta quite that large... it would have been impossible for me to finish it. Absolutely impossible... so yeah, I took a stab and maybe got 20% in. . . 

If you're looking for a place to feel relaxed and enjoy a good meal, this is the place to do it.
author: Annie T.

description:
I LOVE Sodini's -- but if you're going just for great Italian food, this isn't your place.  

Sodini's has been in No. Beach forever, family-owned.  Love the kitschy "Rat Pack" stuff in there, love the bartenders, the lighting, the attitude, the smell -- love everything about it.  Sodini's is an experience -- not a restaurant.  And I hope you will go if you haven't. 

Sodini's is a place to go with a group when you want to talk and drinnk and eat and have a laugh with the staff and feel like you've been someplace that has blood coursing through its veins and history -- and a little dust -- you'll love it.

 IF YOU ARE A FUSSY FOODIE-- PLEASE GO ELSEWHERE.  This  isn't the place to fuss about presentation and take a little taste and try to figure out what is in it -- you will just be disappointed and your unhappiness will ruin the ambience. 

This is a place to quaff inexpensive red wine and eat pasta and talk with friends and gesture with your hands and wish your grandparents had been Italian living in No. Beach in the 1940s...

HERE'S TO LIFE!
author: L M.

description: Sodini's is a San Francisco landmark.  My grandfather used to have lunch there in the 1930s.   If you are a Native San Franciscan, or just wish you were- this is the place to be.  The Bartender, Ana, is AWESOME.  Not only does she make a great martini but she herself is a SF Icon.  Ana can tell you stories about the city and North Beach because she knows the history like no one else.   Everyone that goes in there goes to see Ana because she is the free entertainment at the restaurant.   The food is good, the waitresses are great but the bar scene is the main event.   I always can count on running into someone  I grew up with in here.  Definitely a place to go for anyone who wants to know where the natives go
author: P S.

description: I've been going to Sodini's for over ten years now and I'm looking forward to many more. Anything pesto, the pizza, and gnocchi! Perfect atmosphere for a date or a few friends. The salad dressing is epic as well. And great drinks to top it all off!
author: Matt A.

description: The best part of the meal was the bread. I think that says enough. From italian places, I always get the frutti di mare (here known as the seafood linguini). This one just wasn't very flavorful or appetizing. Our calamari appetizer wasnt worth what we paid for it. My boyfriend's dish was so unmemorable that I don't even remember what he got. To top it off, the service was incredibly slow and it only aggravated the situation. I didn't need to spend an extra 20 minutes waiting for the check I'd asked for! I couldn't help wishing that I had saved the $60 for our meal and spent it at Pasta Pomodoro or pretty much anywhere else instead. Definitely not coming back.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
LOVE this place.  Very friendly neighborhood feel.  The staff is warm and  welcoming.  

The food is absolutely amazing.  Words cannot describe.  My Italian relatives in New York would be happy to know that I'm living in a city with this caliber of authentic Italian food.  

Cannot say enough good things about Sodini's.  Love it.
author: Rachel M.

description:
A nice place.  The food was much better than the normal tourist trap places that litter North Beach, and the atmosphere is simple and non-pretentious.

The only issue I had with this place is the long, long wait for a table.

Now, I understand that places get busy.  And this place is BUSY on the weekends.   

Since they don't take reservations, I also understand that you're going to have to wait.  

BUT while I was waiting for a table, I also couldn't help notice that the system to turn over tables seemed pretty unorganized which slows...things...down.  For example: the hostess was also waitressing tables, and seemed frantically busy trying to manage both duties.  Also, once a table was vacated, there was rarely anyone immediately available to clear the table & set-it.  10 minutes to clear & set a table when there's an hour wait to sit down? That's just crazy...and when I'm hungry & I keep seeing this, I kind of lose my shit, you know?

I would definitely come back here, but would think three times before doing so on a weekend.
author: Shawn S.

description: the best old school italian food in north beach....the knocchi in a creamy tomato sauce..an the drinks are killer..great help..great service  if they are busy ask to eat at the bar.
author: Zane L.

description:
No frills tasteless Italian food.  Girly girl and I went, spent $100 on calamari, chicken marsala, lasagna and a pitcher of house red.  A lot of food but poor quality and boring.  
Would rather have spent the $100 anywhere else such as Firefly or Range.
author: balthazar b.

description:
Hands down our favorite restaurant in the city. When we moved to this neighborhood we ate here three times a week for about three months and never had a bad meal.

The carbonara is delicious, but my fave is the ravioli sodini, which comes smothered in the most delicious cheese sauce I've ever tasted, and have been trying to replicate at home ever since.  We've tried most everything on the menu so I recommend it all.

The service is always friendly, but they don't take reservations, so prepare to wait at the bar and have a drink with the locals, quite a colorful bunch.

It's dark inside, with candles on the tables, so it's a great place for a romantic date.
author: Jamie C.

description:
"No reservations.  No decaf.  No dessert."  NO GOOD FOOD!

Don't bother.  This is not good Italian.  The only good thing is their cool old school bar and friendly bartender.
author: Scott W.

description: finding a bad restaurant in san francisco is not easy, finding a bad italian restaurant even more difficult. this one is such a find. pasta a la casa tastes like a cheap ready made sauce. not good
author: Julian H.

description: Such s cute family owned restaurant! Yummy food!
author: Miranda H.

description: Second time dining here, and we love this place.  Be prepared for a slow paced meal,  no rushing here, so if you are in a hurry, go somewhere else.  My hubby had the chicken sodini, chicken needed to be fatter and jucier to gain an extra star.  My caesar salad was fabulous, and the linguine with seafood a huge portion of yummy calamari, clams and shrimp.  the place is authentic italian, amazing dishes were served all around us, lasagna looked especially good.  You will love this little place.
author: Neice K.

description:
Maybe it was because I was super hungry when we got here.  Maybe it was becasue I knocked back a few drinks while waiting at the bar to be seated... but I really loved this place.  

The ambiance is really cool, the staff were super nice and friendly, the food was great and the portions were big.  What's not to like?

I am usually not too excited about Italian restaurants (maybe I've been to the Olive Garden one too many times), but I am looking forward to going back to Sodini's.

For the record I had the Calamari appetizer (mmmm) and the Seafood Linguine.  Yes, I ate it all.  Plus bread and a bunch of drinks. You got a problem with that?
author: Darren G.

description:
To me, Italian restaurants are supposed to have a familiar and welcoming atmosphere, usually pretty loud from people talking or maybe because of people playing instruments. I usually can't associate fancy places with Italian restaurants, to me it just doesn't happen. So I decided to check this place out when I read in Yelp that this is a true Italian restaurant with authentic food. 

Indeed, the environment is as authentic as it can be. Low lights, small crowded place with cheerful waitresses and hostess. My husband and I were meeting two other friends there for dinner this last Saturday, hoping that we could go after dinner check out the 4th of July fireworks in Marina. To make that happen, my friends arrived in the restaurant a little before 7pm. We only made it at 8pm, but we didn't get sit before 8:30pm anyways, so that was a 1,5hs waiting. If I was the one waiting there I am sure it would have made my experience a lot different... but anyways, the bartender was pretty nice to my friend, offering her a garlic bread that was very tasteful.

When we got to our table, the service was very efficient and fast even though the restaurant was very crowded. And again, our waitress was all smiles. We ordered the clams and mussels for appetizer and we shared it amongst 3 people. It was delicious with the garlic bread that they brought to the table once again. We also ordered polenta, but I thought it was plain. 

For the appetizer I was pretty set on fusili, but there weren't many appealing sauces to me. I am a red sauce person with tomato chunks and other chunky stuff to go with it, but it just didn't exist in the menu. You would think italian food can be very versatile, allowing you to mix and match different sauces to pastas, but it wasn't the case at this restaurant. So I ended up choosing the white creamy sauce fusili with prawns. My first disappointment was that the pasta wasn't home made (at least didn't taste anything special) and the sauce was pretty plain and tasteless.

Even though I wasn't very excited about my dish, I would give this restaurant another try for a couple of reasons: everybody there is pretty friendly and they do a good job in creating an italian atmosphere in the restaurant, I am curious to try their pesto nhoqui, their house wine is pretty good and I didn't have to wait 90 minutes to get a table at my first time! ;)
author: Camila E.

description:
Isn't there a Billy Joel song about this place?  
Try the gnocchi with meat sauce.
author: steven k.

description:
Excellent food and service. Portions are large so we ordered an steamed shellfish appetizer and Veal Marsala and shared it.  They were happy to accommodate the sharing.  The veal included soup so we had a 3 course meal. They brought in each course and gave us enough time to finish them before bringing in the next. 

My only gripe is they don't have a desert menu.
author: Harry C.

description:
Great rustic little authentic Italian place with lots of memorabilia and charm. 

The food tastes home-cooked and the staff were very friendly. 

This is where you take your parents or grandparents when they want to eat out. Its quiet enough to have a conversation and comfy enough to feel like your eating dinner at someone's house.

I need to go back!
author: John Eric S.

description: Linda was a phenomal server and Ana served up a great time at the bar. Couldn't have asked for a better dinner or time!
author: Blake D.

description: Enjoyed a great meal here. We shared a pizza with pepperoni, italian sausage, and garlic, as well as pesto gnocci. Both were really good.
author: Jennifer R.

description: This is a great place in north beach. Great bar to drink at while you wait for a table. I have to say the pesto wasn't awesome (hence the 4/5 stars), but everything else has been. Plus, the staff here are friendly and down to earth, which really wins me over when it comes to tourist zones where I actually live. Share an entree and appetizer while drinking the house red wine.
author: Paigey B.

description: Unfortunately it has been a few weeks since my trip to San Francisco so my recollection of my meal at Sodini's won't be so exact, but I CAN say the service was fast and friendly and my entree - the tortellini con pesto - pleasurable and plentiful. A Saturday night, the restaurant buzzed, and while I dined alone and therefore had no difficulty securing a seat at the bar for both drinks and my dinner, I did not witness too many people milling about for unnecessarily long periods while waiting for a table.
author: Hugh R.

description:
This place is always fun, you get to draw on the table paper (big plus for me), the wine is cheap, and the food is usually cheesy and good :)

I'm a sucker for good and cheap Italian food that is unpretentious and down to earth.  

I'll always go back to this place, and continue to reccomend it to friends.
author: Kristin E.

description: Excellent house salad, pasta dishes and chicken parmigiana. Very warm, pleasant place for a casual meal.
author: Suzanne S.

description: I love this place!  a local recommended it to me and I go every time I am in North Beach.  Down home family italian cookin'!  The staff is great.  They even brought us a serving of brochetta on the house!  I wish they had desert, but I can walk up the street for that...the sauces here are delicious!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
What sticks in my mind about my visit to Sodini's were the little plastic grape clusters that illuminated a couple of spots in the restaurant with a reddish glow. I'm not sure if that's a good thing but it fit in with the homey, neighborhood eatery feeling that hits you when you enter.

Bread and water were promptly brought to our table but it took quite a while before anyone approached us to take our order. The starter salad we ordered was ample enough for two to share and if you order a meat entree you get a choice between that or the soup. I opted for my standard order of ravioli and white cream sauce which was all right but I'm thinking that I should've ordered something else. Something that didn't require as much... finesse maybe.

And oh yeah, the parking... be prepared for a hike if you don't find parking in front.
author: Kristi K.

description:
I keep hearing all these "Man, we were seated at 7:30 on a Sunday" or we were seated at 8:00 on a Friday night!"

It's because this place sucks!

No greetings when we walked in. I looked around as if perhaps we had to seat ourselves. As we walk to a table, someone comes up and says, "2 for dinner?" Yeah, like five minutes later! So I nod my head and she takes us to another table. Whatever.

The floor plan is somewhat crowded. I mean, it's just hard to sit and not be in other people's conversations. It just sucks. And then!!! You get these loud people next to you...not good.

So...what else? Oh!

The waitress was never around. Our food took over 40 minutes to show up. I have to call it food, because it came from the menu, but I would never safely say that it was food. I ordered the cheese and beef raviolli, but don't remember ever tasting any beef in my mouth. A shame...

The most frustrating thing was that we were so hungry and we easily devoured the basket of bread. And they took it away and brought out another basket of bread. That one was done and they brought out more.

Finally as the bus boy sets down the basket of bread, I touch his arm and say, "Listen, I don't remember ordering bread. I remember ordering raviolli. Is that, oh I don't know, coming anytime soon? Cause you can let me know. Really, you can. But I'm hungry and getting sick and tired of your stale bread."

All I heard was "Lemme check" and I never saw that many again. Not even walking through the restaurant.

[I am sorry that I frightened you little bus boy person...]

I will say, to all those 5-star reviews...the reason you get seated so quickly is because no one is ever here. And if that's what you call "authentic Italian food"...then Italy must suck something fierce...

The one star is because they were playing music from The Four Seasons all night. That's ok by me. :)
author: Nicolas H.

description: The place is small and the entrance is not too inviting but the food is super delicious!!! The lasange and the carbonara were excellent. Portions are generous. Kid friendly. Will definetly go back.
author: E. Y. G.

description:
Solid Italian food in the heart of North Beach.
No reservation, No Desert, No Decaf= You have it our way, if you want it your way, go to Burger King.
And I completely agree with the approach because it seems like everyone tries to make their own menus which is a complete insult to any competent chef.
author: Fabio.lous f.

description: It's good to feel like a VIP sometimes. My friends are well known by the servers, so a table was ready for us as we left one of the many watering holes in the area. Sodini's has a nice atmosphere, it small and homely, like when I use to eat dinner in my kitchen nook. The food is good and reasonably priced. We ordered Seafood Alfredo, Bruchetta Garlic Bread, and Sausage and Pepperoni Pizza. It's a crowded, busy joint with great service. I loved the old motown tunes playing in the back ground with pictures up of the Rat Pack. Finding parking maybe the only issue of being a frequent customer here.
author: Dennis S.

description:
Quality east-coast style Italian, good atmosphere and fun.  Too bad the management is sometimes unpleasant.

Would get five stars for food alone.
author: The P.

description:
Reading all the reviews, I was expecting something extra or special about this place. It isn't bad but it wasn't spectacular either. Restaurant was small and cozy. The restaurant does fill up but I was lucky and got there before the dinner rush, so I was seated immediately. There is a full bar inside with TV for sports games, etc. Sat at a table in the dining area. Friendly service. Decent to good food. I had their calamari (It was just ok. I did really like their tartar sauce though). And their gnocci with pesto sauce was good. All in all a good dinner, but not anything extra ordinary. I'd come here again (mainly because it's so conveniently located for me) for casual dinner with a couple friends or with the boyfriend. But probably not more than a party of 4 in my opinion. 

Oh, and the restaurant doesn't say anything about Green Valley on their signs, though it probably does say "Sodini's". But if you're like me and have trouble remembering names, I'd stick with just the number address :)
author: Nhi T.

description:
Sodini's is the REAL North Beach dining experience! This establishment  is an authentic gem, snuggled right in the heart of North Beach. It's the real deal: a family-run spot for years and years, and the best place you can go for an intimate, yet energetic vibe.

Ana, the charismatic bartender, makes you feel special from the moment you walk through the door. Once you're in her charming presence, you will feel as though you've found the magic key which unlocks all things fun and legendary about San Francisco. Relax yourself on a seat at the beautiful wood bar, and before you know it, she has set you up with a lovely libation of your choice, and somehow has already introduced you to some the North Beach locals that consider this place a favorite. Ana has the rare gift of being professional, beautiful, entertaining, and capable of mixing you the best damn drink anywhere in town. It's miraculous just watching her do it all with such style and grace. Plus, she's a North Beach native! R-E-S-P-E-C-T!

I love the sense of comfortable familiarity this place gives me, while at the same time; I always enjoy meeting the interesting newcomers this place seems to attract. Individuals and families from across the globe find their way to this spot, bringing with them a feeling of freshness that compliments the intimate atmosphere here. Sodini's is the perfect spot for a romantic date, and yet it simultaneously is completely great for a friendly get-together. 

There's a reason that people always come back to Sodini's: because it hits the perfect cord every time. The menu is traditional, and deeply satisfying. This is exactly what you're looking for, whether you know it yet, or not. Once you give it a try, you'll see what I mean. 

The staff will very competently make sure you are well taken care of, and the tone of the service is very genuine without being overly solicitous. In other words, they are not annoying drones. You will find their style very refreshing, because they know their stuff, and they do it right. After returning a few times, you'll find yourself on a first name basis with them. Familiar faces- that's the best! Plus, Mark Sodini is THE quintessential proprietor.

This is not an Olive Garden type of place. Instead, you'll experience the satisfaction of discovering what the genuine, old-school North Beach is truly all about! 

Afterwards, it's fabulous to stroll around the neighborhood streets, taking in the gorgeous architecture, Washington Square Park, or the cafes and gelaterias, which stay open late. You may even find yourself stumbling into some of San Francisco's legendary jazz, blues or rock clubs- you never know!
author: Holly H.

description:
Great little joint...
Nice atmosphere. Get there early or you will wait cuz there are few seats.

Only open at night so I had to refrain from the pizza place two doors down, but I was strong.
author: M J.

description:
Good.  Not "oh my god, I can die now because this is fantastic Italian".  But, good.  I will return.  There are a TON of pasta choices so this is definitely a carb-junkie haven. 

Came here with some out of towners, so of course we MUST go to North Beach.  Sodini's is definitely better than the other touristy NoBeach restos around.  But, it is still not as good as its original counterpart (Bertolucci's).  

I ordered shrimp linguine with sodini sauce.  Big prawns, so that's nice (I hate feeling jipped by tiny shrimpettes).  My party ordered the seafood linguine with tomato cream sauce - very good, linguine with pesto - eh... u can pass on this, and something that looks like a baked ziti - also passable. 

I really did like the scene though.  Very..... rat packish.  (If you don't know who or what rat pack is... then so help you god).
author: Sammi C.

description: Started off with a fabulous glass of sauvigionese. The bruschetta was mouth watering... The rack of lamb was a bit disappointing but only because I believe it was overcooked. I ordered medium rare but came out medium well. I couldn't really confirm since the lighting is dark but definitely not a red toasty middle with juices oozing. Didn't want to have to send it back since it'd be another 20 to redo it. The pesto pasto that came with it was average but definitely not the best pesto I've ever had. I'll try giving it another shot though. The service was excellent though.
author: Helen V.

description: If you are looking for authentic, inexpensive, delicious North beach Italian, this is your spot. Wonderful staff and more character than you can wish for. Our favorite!!!!
author: Bill S.

description:
I like it.  They have good hearty food.  Granted that is very non-descriptive for Italian, but they have the basics.  Meatballs are good as is the house salad.  The only drawback is, it's super loud, and they don't take reservations.  Super bummer, so if the bar is full, be prepared to walk the neighborhood for an hr.

Also no parking, it is north beach.  Walk or take a cab.

Update as of 4/10/2008...

You have got to be kidding me.  Went last night and I almost died.  I had fond memories of this spot.  He ordered the stuffed pork chop. DO NOT ORDER THIS.  IT WAS RAW.  AND WHEN I SAY RAW, I MEAN RAW AS IN SEARED TUNA RAW.  Initially we thought, huh maybe this is prosciutto inside, no.  This was sent back not to be touched again and we picked at my 'baked' penne.  This what not even backed, had watery sauce just not good.  I felt bad for my date as I have had good meals here before, but the quality is at an all time low.
author: Nicole F.

description:
Although this place is nestled in North Beach amid all the other small Italian restaurants, I think this place is special. It really feels like you're eating in someone's living room, which I like. Seems like other people think this place is special too, because it gets crowded quickly. If it happens to be crowded and cramped on a Friday or Saturday night, just be patient. You can always get a drink at the bar beforehand. 

The food is traditional Italian food and cooked very well. Service seems to be good for the most part but maybe a little spread thin when it gets really busy. Though, I must say that we weren't left waiting or hungry for too long. The front bar certainly helps with the patience...
author: Kimi W.

description:
Sodini's is a great spot for rich, classic italian food. The service has always been good - especially the Bartender!

My favorite dish is the linguine and clams! it's by far some of the best I've ever had! 

The atmosphere is very old school, so if you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city and enjoy some great linguine - this is the spot!
author: jen v.

description:
After a recommendation, I went here with my family and we shared several dishes.
